issue.title: Considering using Mockito / AssertJ / Hamcrest in Leshan
issue.body:
Initially [**Mockito**](https://site.mockito.org/) was used in Leshan but : 
- We have feeling that code written with it was not so good.
- We didn't use it so much.

So, we decide to remove this dependency. 

But  : 
- reading the doc about it, I feel this is possible to write pretty clean code with it, especially now we are targeting java8 (and no more java7).
- especially is you want [to check if callback is called 1 or several times](https://javadoc.io/doc/org.mockito/mockito-core/latest/org/mockito/Mockito.html#exact_verification)  (we need it for testing https://github.com/eclipse/leshan/issues/1385#issuecomment-1403868494)
- this was also asked by some contributor by the past  (https://github.com/eclipse/leshan/issues/1228#issuecomment-1142210076)

Anyway if we do that move this will be after #1381.

(This discussion lead to question about [**Hamcrest** ](https://hamcrest.org/JavaHamcrest/)and [**AssertJ**](https://github.com/assertj/assertj) too)

issue.title: Add `ArgumentMatchers#assertArg` method.

repository.name: mockito
repository.description: Most popular Mocking framework for unit tests written in Java

issue.body:
Fixes #2285

Enables convenient alternative to `ArgumentCaptor` to assert arguments during verification:

```java
verify(otherServiceMock).doStuff(assertArg(param -> {
    assertThat(param.getField1()).isEqualTo("value1");
    assertThat(param.getField2()).isEqualTo("value2");
}));
```

Verification succeeds as long as no exception is thrown from the lambda passed to `assertArg`, which means it works with any assertions (JUnit, AssertJ, ...).

Since this is my first PR to Mockito, I may have missed something, or perhaps the documentation should be improved. Feedback is very welcome!

issue.title: Assertion matcher

repository.name: mockito
repository.description: Most popular Mocking framework for unit tests written in Java

issue.body:
`ArgumentMatcher` returns true/false and it's enough for stubs.
However, for mocks false is not enough. When expectation is not meet, it is important why not meet. It means _rich-failure_ is needed, not just `false`

Actually _rich-failure_ can be achieved with `org.assertj.core.matcher.AssertionMatcher`.
It works but it's not handy: every assertion needs a class, when lambda is enough
